Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Persistence of Informal Economies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Theories of economic development have long predicted that employment outside of formal, regulated organizations would eventually become obsolete, but informal economies continue to provide a livelihood to around 60 percent of workers in poorer countries and 30 percent in richer ones. India is a particularly important case when studying informal economies because over 90 percent of its workforce is informal. This project analyzes informal waste collection and recycling in Delhi, India, which, despite challenges from legal and private actors, continues to persist and facilitate positive environmental outcomes in India?s capital city. The research asks: What are the relationships and institutions that allow the informal recycling workforce to thrive in spite of private opposition and formal regulation?

The project is designed as an extended case study, which assembles original ethnographic data to revise and build sociological theory on the relationship of state and market institutions to informal urban economies. The primary data to be collected are extensive participation observation with informal recyclers and at least 125 interviews with informal recyclers and legal actors. Two hypothetical positions are examined: the first holds that there is a division between higher and lower levels of legal operation, which results in support for informal enterprise at the local level despite high level disavowal, and a second proposes that while social relations such as kinship and ethnicity prevail within singular informal enterprises, market relations are a primary source of regulation between these informal enterprises.

This project takes steps to understand urban processes in the twenty-first century. From the global cities literature, we know that cities are becoming increasingly connected through markets. However, that research attends only to the world?s wealthiest cities and takes a high-level perspective, when what is needed are more detailed analyses of how global flows and local practices combine to produce urban change. This study draws on sociological tools to open up the "black box" of urban informality and theorize how it is produced from the ground up. A detailed look at negotiations between informal actors and those in market and legal institutions provides an opportunity to revise essential sociological theory, while the combined focus on structural barriers and potential for agency holds promise as a paradigm for future urban research. Understanding the formal ties of informal work allows researchers to contribute to the difficult question of how to create change where formal institutions are less strong. Additionally, there is a need to study informal practices that contribute to an urban sustainability agenda. This project addresses both of these issues in a context where approaches to waste management could be revised to produce more positive social and environmental outcomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Informality has been traditionally defined in terms of its deficiencies, especially a lack of state regulation and taxation, where a formal domain stands as the category of reference. However, a country where the informal economy comprises the majority workforce (estimated at 93% in India) suggests the need for an approach that considers informal work not only as residual or exploited, but rather as a primary domain that requires an analysis in its own right as a market. This approach extends work in economic sociology to the study of informal markets in urban settings, arguing that the sociality of markets becomes more visible in a context where bureaucracy is diminished and social relations are the explicit ties that bind actors who exchange. 

            The first source of regulation on informal recycling chains is the demand for recycled materials. Waste collectors at the bottom of the chain (often called “rag pickers” in India and “waste pickers” in much of the world) are typically depicted as an isolated, desperate lot. But, this perspective ignores that the workforce is actually the labor that sources inputs for a larger recycling business—an industry that traverses both informal (unregistered) and formal (registered) enterprises as it moves from procuring materials from garbage to re-processing them into new products. While cities have long had groups of people who live off of its waste (e.g. London’s nightsoil collectors), the changing material of waste products—earlier consisting of human, plant, and animal wastes and now including plastics, metals, and paper—has led to a transformation in the systems that exist to process these materials. In this regard, plastic is especially interesting because it is a relatively new material that has proliferated at a rapid pace since the 1950s and created new markets for re-processing in the wake of its expansion. To follow these market chains, I met with the buyers of materials from waste collectors, and I plan to follow these for a few materials until I am able to see what they are made into at the final stage. This method allowed me to assess the social bases for business at various points in the chain (collection, buying, re-processing) and trace the links between formality and informality as the materials move between the two.

The second cluster of sources of regulation emanate from state agencies and officials, which range significantly from local to the national level and include a variety of agencies and hierarchies. Sanitation has been described as the “primary responsibility” of the municipality in my initial meetings with these street-level bureaucrats, and it features significantly into local politics, yet the bulk of the actual trash collection work, and all recycling activities, are carried out by non-state employees. My research has revealed that many informal collectors are directly related to the formal municipal system in two ways. First, nearly all collectors work beneath a contractor, who collects a monthly fee from households. The second way that informal collectors engage with the formal system is by buying the garbage collected by government door-to-door collection trucks.

            Finally, there are social sources of regulation. If the “waste picker” at the bottom of the pyramid is typically portrayed as a figure relegated to this work due to their caste background and association with dirty work, my research has found that many waste collectors are first generation workers in this sector, and they have moved between other jobs—particularly as farm laborers and rickshaw peddlers. In this sense, class appears to trump caste. Indeed, people are taking up these jobs because they are relatively stable, less physically taxing than alternatives, pay relatively well, and (probably most important), they have friends or family from their hometown that also do this work. Dirt and contamination operate as stigmatizing forces, but they do not appear to be immutable markers. Indeed, collectors have revealed in interviews that they had to negotiate the smell and stigma that comes along with manual waste work when they began doing it, demonstrating that this was not in any way “natural” or even habitual work for them.
